questions.text: A 2-week-old infant presents with lethargy, poor feeding, irritability, and a bulging fontanelle. Born prematurely at 34 weeks with low birth weight, a lumbar puncture reveals cloudy cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) with high white blood cell count, decreased glucose, and elevated protein levels. Which is not a causative factor for this infant's condition?
questions.solution:
Correct answer- C)Streptococcus pneumoniae

While Streptococcus pneumoniae is a significant cause of bacterial meningitis in children and adults, it is less common in neonates. Given the infant's age, prematurity, and other clinical factors, it is less likely to be the causative organism.

 

Bacterial meningitis in neonates and children

Common Causes by Age Group

Neonates

Pre-school Children

Older Children
  • Escherichia coli (gram-negative bacilli)
  • Group B streptococci
  • Listeria monocytogenes (Option A, B and D ruled out)
  • Haemophilus influenzae type b
  • Neisseria meningitidis
  • Streptococcus pneumoniae
  • Neisseria meningitidis
  • Streptococcus pneumoniae

Clinical Features

Lethargy, fever, hypothermia, seizure, headache, stiff neck, irritability, drowsiness, and vomiting.

Diagnosis

Lumbar puncture (CSF analysis):

  • Cloudy CSF with high white blood cell count (neutrophils)
  • Elevated protein, decreased glucose

Gram stain or culture reveals bacteria

Treatment

Empirical antibiotics: Broad-spectrum antibiotics started immediately

Targeted antibiotics: Based on causative bacteria

Adjunctive glucocorticoid therapy.

Complications

Hearing loss (common with H. influenzae and S. pneumoniae), seizures, memory impairment, decreased intellectual function, hydrocephalus, sepsis, and risk of death

Prevention

Vaccination: Against H. influenzae type b, N. meningitidis

Chemoprophylaxis: Prophylactic antibiotics for close contacts of meningococcal meningitis cases.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents to the emergency with fever, severe headache and confusion for last 3 days. Nuchal rigidity is present. Fundus is normal. CSF study shows 1000 cells with 10% lymphocytes and 90% PMN cells , CSF /plasma sugar 0.4 and CSF protein 80 mg/dl. What is the next best step in managment of this patient?

choices.text: IV Cannula and start IV fluids at 20 ml per kg per hour

questions.solution:
The clinical features and lumbar puncture findings of high WBC, with the predominance of neutrophils, low sugar and elevated protein point to bacterial meningitis. Immediate initiation of intravenous broad-spectrum antibiotics is essential due to high mortality. Steps to be followed will be 

1. IV cannulation and draw blood culture ( Meningitis patients can develop SIADH so need restricted IV fluids) 

2.  Perform LP afer ruling out raised ICP or focal neurolgical deficit. If any one present Neuroimaging to be done first ( in this case Fundus examination was normal) 

3. Empirical antibiotics after CSF microscopy ( start antibiotics within one hour of hospitalization)

questions.text: Which of the following accurately describes the CSF findings in viral encephalitis caused by HSV-1?

choices.text: Lymphocytic pleocytosis with low glucose levels
Lymphocytic pleocytosis with normal glucose levels
Lymphocytic pleocytosis with cob web coagulum
Lymphocytic pleocytosis with elevated glucose levels

questions.solution:
Correct answer- B) Lymphocytic pleocytosis with normal glucose levels

In cases of viral encephalitis, particularly caused by HSV-1, the CSF usually demonstrates an increased number of lymphocytes, indicating a viral infection. Glucose levels remain normal, which helps differentiate it from bacterial meningitis, where glucose is often low.

 

HSV Encephalitis Diagnosis

CSF Analysis

PCR

Neuroimaging and EEG

  • Shows lymphocytic pleocytosis (increased lymphocytes).
  • Normal glucose levels.
  • Slightly elevated protein concentration.

CSF PCR for HSV is highly sensitive (96%) and specific (99%) for confirming diagnosis.
  • MRI is preferred for early detection of HSV encephalitis. Characteristic lesions appear on T2-weighted and diffusion-weighted MRI, affecting the orbitofrontal and temporal lobes.
  • EEG may show periodic slow-wave activity in the temporal lobes, indicative of HSV encephalitis.

HSV Encephalitis - T2 MRI showing high signal in Temporal lobe

questions.text: A 25 year old HIV positive male is brought to the emergency after developing high grade fever and altered sensorium for past 2 days. Meningeal signs are absent and bilateral babinski sign is noted. MRI head shows predominant temporal lobe inflammation. Which of the following is correct about immediate managment of this patient?

choices.text: Start empirical Liposomal amphotericin B with 5 flucytosine

questions.solution:
Correct answer: B: Start Empirical acyclovir

The key words of temporal lobe invovlement in a patient with short duration illness causing altered sensoroium points to HSV-1 encephalitis. HIV positive status does not change the etiology of viral meningitis. It is still HSV-1 encephaltiis Any delay in starting acyclovir can cause permanent neurological deficits, including memory loss, difficulty with speech, and personality changes.

Balbinski sign implies bilateral corticospinal tract is involved due to encephalitis. Absence of meningeal signs indicates parenchymal involvement. 

Option A is for cerebral malaria. Option B for TBM and option D for cryptococcal meningitis

questions.text: A 45 y/o male with a history of HIV infection presents to the ED with headache, fever, photophobia, and neck stiffness. His CD4 count is 80 cells/mm³. Lumbar puncture reveals an elevated opening pressure, low glucose, and elevated protein levels. India ink staining of the cerebrospinal fluid showed the following picture. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial treatment regimen for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: B) Amphotericin B and Flucytosine

 

Explanation:

The patient's presentation is consistent with cryptococcal meningitis, as indicated by the encapsulated yeast cells on India ink staining, most commonly caused by Cryptococcus neoformans. The recommended initial treatment is a combination of amphotericin B and flucytosine for induction therapy, followed by fluconazole for consolidation.

 

Fungal meningitis:

Causes
  • Cryptococcus neoformans (most common)
  • Candida
  • Histoplasma
  • Blastomyces
  • Coccidioides
  • Sporothrix

Risk factors

Immunocompromised patients

Clinical features
  • Headache
  • Altered mental status, lethargy
  • Fever
  • Neck stiffness
  • Nausea and vomiting.

Investigations
  • Lumbar Puncture: Low glucose and high protein levels. White cell count can be normal or higher than 20 microL and have a lymphocyte predominance.
  • India ink stain shows encapsulated yeast cells.
  • CSF ELISA for CRAG (Cryptococcal Antigen).

Treatment

(Options A, C & D ruled out)
  • LAMB (Liposomal Amphotericin-B) and 5-Fluorocytosine (Flucytosine) for 2 weeks
  • Fluconazole is given subsequently for 8-10 weeks.

questions.text: During a lumbar puncture, the needle passes through several anatomical layers before reaching the subarachnoid space. Which of the following is the correct sequence of structures pierced during this procedure?

choices.text: Skin → Ligamentum flavum → Supraspinous ligament → Interspinous ligament → Dura → Arachnoid
Skin → Supraspinous ligament → Interspinous ligament → Ligamentum flavum → Arachnoid → Dura
Skin → Supraspinous ligament → Ligamentum flavum → Interspinous ligament → Dura → Arachnoid
Skin → Supraspinous ligament → Interspinous ligament → Ligamentum flavum → Dura → Arachnoid

questions.solution:
Correct answer is Option D 

Mnemonic for structures pierced while performing lumbar puncture: "Some Say I Like Drinking Alcohol"

  • Skin

  • Supraspinous ligament

  • Interspinous ligament

  • Ligamentum flavum

  • Dura

  • Arachnoid

questions.text: Which of the following is not required for management of Post dural puncture headache?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is C ) Bladder catheterization and laxatives

  • Postdural puncture headache (PDPH) is a potential complication of a lumbar puncture, with symptoms caused by traction on pain-sensitive structures from low cerebrospinal fluid pressure (intracranial hypotension) following a leak of cerebrospinal fluid at the puncture site.
  • Mainstay of management is Bed rest, hydration, analgesia. 
  • If headache persists inspite of use of caffiene ( Drug of choice for PDPH) and opoids then Low volume blood patch is used.

questions.text: A 38 year old man presented to ER with inability to stand and sit up in bed since yesterday evening. He reports that the weakness began as slipping in stairs multiple times in last 3 days along with  tingling in his fingertips. Power in both legs at all joints is grade 2/5 and bilateral ankle jerks are absent. Which is not correct about this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is B: MRI shows spinal cord inflammation

The diagnosis based on symetrical flaccid paralysis with arreflexia and ascending nature is GBS ( cant walk followed by cant sit). The condition spares bladder and bowel. MRI spine will show dorsal nerve root demyelination and not inflammation. Inflammation is seen in transverse myleitis. CSF studt shows cytoabuminological dissociation. Electrodiagnostic study/ nerve conduction velocity will show prolonged or absent F waves due to demyelination affecting proximal nerve segments.

questions.text: A 36 year old HIV positive patient presents with double vision, vomitting epsiodes with daily frontal headaches that dont respond to painkillers. Patient is not cooperative during physical examination due to headache. Fundus examination shows papilledema. Neuroimaging is performed. Which of the following is not correct about immediate management of this patient?

choices.text: Lumbar puncture for CSF CBNAAT for MTB

questions.solution:
Correct answer A:  Lumbar puncture for CSF CBNAAT for MTB

This immunocompromised patient is having ring enhanching lesions seen on MRI head. Lesions show “Target sign” with solid central nodule. First differential diagnosis in india TB meningitis. Due to raised ICP lumbar puncture cannot be performed in this patient as of now due to risk of brain herniation. Empirical ATT with steroids will be started along with measures to lower raised ICP. Double vision is seen this case due to 6th nerve palsy seen in raised ICP. 

Contraindications to Lumbar puncture

  1. Papilledema

  2. Focal neurologic deficit (esp. new onset)

  3. Midline shift or mass on CT/MRI

  4. Bleeding disorders / Anticoagulants

  5. Skin infection at site

  6. Uncontrolled seizures

  7. Signs of raised ICP with impending herniation

questions.text: A 68 year old patient with diabetic nephropathy presents to the ER with fever, headache, and neck stiffness. Blood cultures are pending, and a lumbar puncture reveals elevated CSF protein, decreased glucose, and neutrophilic pleocytosis. Which of the following is the most appropriate empirical antibiotic regimen?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is C: Ampicillin + Ceftriaxone + Vancomycin

  • The diagnosis in this scenario is bacterial meningitis. Due to advanced age of patient along with comoribidity we need to give coverage for streptococcus pneumoniae as well as Listeria monocytogenes plus cover for penicillin‑resistant Streptococcus pneumoniae. 
  • The correct treatment includes Ampicillin for Listeria coverage in addition to Ceftriaxone and Vancomycin for broad-spectrum bacterial coverage including Streptococcus pneumoniae and Neisseria meningitidis

For patients with hospital acquired menngitis, post traumatic meningitis, post neurosurgery or neutropenic patients: Option D will be used 

Antimicrobial Therapy for Meningitis Based on Age and Pathogens:

Age group

Empiric Treatment

Children <3 Months of Age
  • Ampicillin: To cover Listeria monocytogenes
  • Cefotaxime or Ceftriaxone: To cover S. pneumoniae, Group B streptococci, H. influenzae, and N. meningitidis

Children >3 Months to Adults (up to 55 years):
  • Ceftriaxone or Cefotaxime: Covers S. pneumoniae, N. meningitidis, H. influenzae
  • Vancomycin: To cover cephalosporin-resistant S. pneumoniae
  • Dexamethasone: To reduce meningeal inflammation
  • Acyclovir: Added if HSV encephalitis is suspected
  • Doxycycline: Added during tick season to cover tick-borne bacterial infections

Adults >55 Years or Immunocompromised Patients (including pregnancy, chronic illness, organ transplantation, malignancy, or immunosuppressive therapy):
  • Ampicillin: Added for Listeria monocytogenes coverage
  • Ceftriaxone or Cefotaxime: To cover S. pneumoniae, N. meningitidis
  • Vancomycin: To cover resistant S. pneumoniae

For patients with hospital acquired menngitis, post traumatic meningitis, post neurosurgery or neutropenic patients 

 
  • Ceftazidime or Meropenem: For Pseudomonas aeruginosa
  • Vancomycin: Added in case of suspected Staphylococcal infections

questions.text: A 45 y/o patient presents with fever, headache, neck stiffness, and photophobia. On examination, the patient is lethargic and lumbar puncture reveals elevated CSF opening pressure, PMN leukocytosis, decreased glucose levels, and increased protein concentration. Which of the following will not be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is A: Woltman sign 

  • Woltman sign is seen in hypothyroidism and has delayed relaxation phase of ankle jerks due to myxedema of achilles tendon.
  • Kernig sign: With hip and knee flexed at 90 degrees, we extend the knee to meet with stiff hamstrings.
  • Jolt accentuation : ask pateint to turn head left and right at 2-3 turns per second. This will cause worsening of headache.
  • Brudzinki sign: assisted neck flexion will cause involuntary hip and knee joint flexion

questions.text: A 34-year-old male HIV positive truck driver presents with severe headache. Examination shows nuchal rigidity and altered mental status. Lumbar puncture shows elevated opening pressure, low glucose , normal protein  and encapsulated yeast on India ink staining. What is the most appropriate initial treatment?

choices.text: Liposomal amphotericin B with High-dose IV fluconazole

questions.solution:
Correct answer is C: IV amphotericin B plus flucytosine

  • The diagnosis is cryptococcal meningitis because the patient's clinical presentation, including HIV with low CD4+ count, elevated CSF opening pressure, and the identification of encapsulated yeast in the CSF via India ink stain, is characteristic of Cryptococcus neoformans infection.
  • IV amphotericin B plus flucytosine is the standard initial treatment for cryptococcal meningitis to reduce fungal load and manage CNS infection.
  • Amphotericin should be continued until CSF culture is negative, followed by fluconazole (400 mg/d PO for 8 weeks, then 200 mg/d) until CD4+ T-cell count >200 cells/μL for 6 months.

 

Cryptococcal Meningitis

Common Cause

The leading infectious cause of meningitis in AIDS patients is primarily due to Cryptococcus neoformans (C. neoformans); C. gattii accounts for up to 12%.

Clinical Presentation

Symptoms include fever, nausea, vomiting, altered mental status, headache, and meningeal signs.

CSF Profile

It may be normal or show modest elevations in WBC and protein levels with low sugar. 

Diagnosis
  • Identification of organisms via India ink examination of CSF.

IOC is CSF ELISA for cryptococcal antigen 

Induction therapy
  • IV amphotericin B (0.7 mg/kg daily) or liposomal amphotericin (4–6 mg/kg daily) plus flucytosine (25 mg/kg qid) for at least 2 weeks.
  • Monitor renal function to avoid flucytosine toxicity

Maintenance Therapy
  • Amphotericin should be continued until CSF culture is negative, followed by fluconazole (400 mg/d PO for 8 weeks, then 200 mg/d) until CD4+ T-cell count >200 cells/μL for 6 months.

questions.text: A 32 year old HIV-positive truck driver presents with fever, headache and drowsiness. Lumbar puncture is performed, and CSF  shows elevated opening pressure with 20 lymphocytes /cu.mm with low sugar and protein of 60 mg/dl. MRI of the brain is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is B: Cryptococcal meningitis

MRI Brain in HIV positive patient is showing  "soap bubble" appearance which is characteristic of cryptococcal infection. 

Tuberculous meningitis (Option A): Typically presents with a subacute onset, and CSF shows a lymphocytic pleocytosis, low glucose, and high protein; encapsulated yeast is not seen.

Cytomegalovirus encephalitis (Option C): MRI brain will show periventricular and subependymal hyperintensities with contrast enhancement. Lots of time it will co-exist with CMV retinitis showing pizza pie retinopathy. 


Toxoplasmosis (Option D): Usually presents with multiple ring-enhancing lesions on MRI, but does not involve encapsulated yeast or fungal elements in the CSF.

 

 

Staining

Imaging
 

India ink staining of Cryptococcus neoformans

 



 

Gram staining of the CSF reveals clusters of thin-walled, encapsulated yeast forms of various sizes with narrow-based budding consistent with Cryptococcus.

  

MRI showing “Soap bubble appearance” of C.Neoformans

questions.text: A  25 year old HIV positive man presents with complaints of a severe headache, fever, and confusion. His CD4+ T-cell count is 150 cells/μL. Neurological examination reveals right-sided hand weakness and difficulty speaking. An MRI of the patient is given below. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Initiate treatment with sulfadiazine and pyrimethamine with leucovorin
Perform a brain biopsy to confirm the diagnosis.
Order a chest X-ray to rule out tuberculosis.
Start empiric treatment for bacterial meningitis.

questions.solution:
Correct answer is A: Initiate treatment with sulfadiazine and pyrimethamine with leucovorin

  • MRI head shows ring enhancing lesions seen in basal ganglia and corticomedullary junction. They lack the eccentric scolex appearance of NCC or target sign with solid nodule appearance of TB meningitis. TBM also has leptomeningeal enhancement and hydrocephalus. 
  • Ideally we should do MR spectroscopy to distinguish them but here consindering the options given we will consinder cerebral toxoplasmosis. 
  • It a common opportunistic infection in patients with advanced HIV/AIDS, especially with a CD4+ count <200 cells/μL. 
  • Therefore, the appropriate initial management is to start treatment with sulfadiazine and pyrimethamine with leucovorin.

Cerebral Toxoplasmosis

About
  • Toxoplasmosis is a common secondary CNS infection in AIDS patients, but its incidence is decreasing due to ART.
  • Occurs typically when CD4+ T-cell counts are <200/μL.
  • Often represents the reactivation of latent T. gondii tissue cysts.
  • Screening for IgG antibodies to T. gondii is recommended at HIV diagnosis.

Pathophysiology

Cerebral toxoplasmosis usually arises from reactivation of latent cysts.

  • It is 10 times more common in seropositive patients than seronegative ones.
  • Presents with fever, headache, and focal neurological deficits (e.g., seizures, hemiparesis, aphasia).
  • Cerebral oedema may cause confusion, dementia, lethargy, and progressing to coma.

Investigations
  • MRI typically shows multiple lesions with ring enhancement and surrounding oedema.
  • If MRI is unavailable, double-dose contrast CT may be used.
  • Brain biopsy is definitive but reserved for patients who fail 2-4 weeks of empiric therapy.  

Treatment
  • Standard treatment: sulfadiazine + pyrimethamine with leucovorin for 4-6 weeks.
  • Alternatives: clindamycin + pyrimethamine, atovaquone + pyrimethamine, or azithromycin + pyrimethamine + rifabutin.
  • Relapses are common; maintenance therapy (sulfadiazine, pyrimethamine, leucovorin) is recommended if CD4+ T-cell counts <200/μL.
  • Primary prophylaxis: TMP-SMX in patients with CD4+ <100μL and T. gondii IgG.
  • Secondary prophylaxis/maintenance may be discontinued if CD4+ counts >200/μL for 6 months under effective ART.

questions.text: A 42‑year‑old HIV positive man with CD4 count 80 cells/mm³ presents with 3 weeks of visual blurring, weakness in right arm and dysarthria. MRI brain (FLAIR sequence) shows multiple asymmetric hyperintense lesions in the frontal and parietal white matter, with no mass effect and no contrast enhancement. Which of the following is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
​​​​​​Correct answer A: JC virus 

  • MRI shows multiple sub-cortical hyperintense lesions in frontal, parietal and occipital lobes. 
  • The patient’s symptoms, including progressive weakness in her right arm, blurred vision  along with a low CD4+ T-cell count and MRI findings of non-enhancing hyperintense lesions, are consistent with progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (PML) caused by the JC virus.
  • The JC virus in PML infects and destroys oligodendrocytes, leading to demyelination of subcortical white matter tracts. The specific neurological deficits—like visual loss and dysarthria—reflect the location of those demyelinating lesions:
  • The presence of JC virus DNA in the CSF is a key diagnostic marker for PML, with high specificity.
  • No enhancement and minimal mass effect distinguish it from toxoplasmosis (ring‑enhancing) or CMV (ventriculitis, periventricular enhancement). BK virus reactivation is cause of graft failure after kidney transplantation. 

Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy

Etiology 

JC virus is a human polyomavirus; around 80% of adults have antibodies to it, but less than 10% of healthy adults show ongoing replication

Pathophysiology

PML lesions start as small foci of demyelination in the subcortical white matter, eventually coalescing.

Neurological deficits are multifocal and often protracted. Symptoms include ataxia, hemiparesis, visual defects, aphasia, and sensory deficits

nvestigations

MRI shows multiple, non-enhancing white matter lesions, particularly in the occipital and parietal lobes. 

Lesions appear hyperintense on T2-weighted images and hypointense on T1-weighted images.

.

Treatment

No specific treatment exists for PML, but ART has improved survival rates, with some patients surviving >15 years.Before ART, median survival was 3-6 months.

questions.text: 30 year old man from village is admitted with high grade fever and altered sensorium. On examination bilateral babinski and exaggerated ankle jerks noted. Nuchal rigidity is absent. Work up shows Hb:7 gm%, TLC: 10K/cu.mm, platelet count: 1.5 Lac/cu.mm, elevated LDH, LFT is normal and Serum creatinine is 1.5mg/dl. What is best course of action for this patient?

choices.text: Peripheral smear followed by IV Artensunate
Lateral flow assay followed by IV Sulphamethoxazole plus Trimethoprim

questions.solution:
Correct answer: B: Peripheral smear followed by IV Artensunate

The patient is having high grade fever with evidence of brain parenchymal involvement ( bilateral Babinski and brisk DTR) . Evidence of hemolysis is given in form on elevated LDH and low Hb. HRP-2 card tesrt and peripheral smear must be done and empirical Artesunate can be started in this case pending investigations.

Presence of banana shaped gametocytes in peripheral smear with multiple ring stage will confirm the diagnosis of falciparum malaria. The infection makes the RBC sticky causing microinfarctions in brain parenchyma that will explain the development of altered sensorium.
